string.text: Flamethrower "Maxofob"

Selfmade jet flamethrower. This miracle was made in the open air. It is distinguished by good arrogance and simple design. 
 
%c[default]ATTACHMENTS: 
%c[ui_red] ï not available
Flamethrower tank

Selfmade tank with a mixture of fuel, which is used by the flamethrower "Makshoob", which is produced in very limited batches by local craftsmen. 
 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] Punches through the armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]I
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170] huge
Flamethrower

Selfmade jet flamethrower, assembled by pyrotechnic mechanic from improvised materials. Long range does not differ, the reliability is medium. Well demoralizes the opponents. 
 
%c[default]ATTACHMENTS: 
%c[ui_red] ï %c[ui_red] not available
Flamethrower tank

A flame-retardant tank for a hand flamethrower that was assembled by hand somewhere in the Zone. 
 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] Punches through the armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]I
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]huge
Light grenade

Special means of non-lethal action, used for lighting purposes. Are in service with the army, law enforcement agencies and special services.
 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] ï %c[0,170,170,170]none
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] Explosion radius: %c[0,170,170,170]none
%c[0,93,0,0,116] ï %c[0,140,140,140,140] Fragmentation radius: %c[0,170,170,170]none
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] Number of fragments: %c[0,170,170,170]none
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[default] Blast delay: %c[0,170,170,170]~4 seconds
MP 40

The MP 40 submachine gun, often mistakenly referred to as the "Schmeisser", was developed by the German designer Volmer at ERMA Werke for the German Armed Forces, and was put into service by the Wehrmacht in 1938. The design of the new submachine gun was based on the experimental ERMA MP 36, which was developed in 1936 on the basis of the ERMA EMP submachine gun and differed from it by its new layout with a pistol grip, folding buttstock and lower magazine mount. Initially they were intended for arming paratroopers and crews of combat vehicles, but later they were also used by infantry units of the Wehrmacht and the SS.
 
%c[0,140,140,140,140]TOTAL EQUIPMENT: 
 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[0,140,140,140,140,140] silencers of 9x19 mm caliber
MP 40 (worn out)

Worn MP 40 submachine gun, often mistakenly referred to as the "Schmeisser", was developed by the German designer Volmer at ERMA Werke for the German Armed Forces, and was put into service by the Wehrmacht in 1938. The design of the new submachine gun was based on the experimental ERMA MP 36, which was developed in 1936 on the basis of the ERMA EMP submachine gun and differed from it by its new layout with a pistol grip, folding buttstock and lower magazine mount. Initially they were intended for arming paratroopers and crews of combat vehicles, but later they were also used by infantry units of the Wehrmacht and the SS.
 
%c[0,140,140,140,140]TOTAL EQUIPMENT: 
 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] ï %c[0,140,140,140,140,140] silencers of 9x19 mm caliber
An anti-personnel mine

Metal shell projectile designed to be installed underground, on the ground or near the ground or other surface. Triggers when the load exceeds 5 kg.

Details for small arms

Separate parts from the disassembled shotguns and machine guns. Can be used as a basis for the creation of some kind of small arms.

Duplex frame

Duplex frame assembled from various parts from disassembled shotguns and machine guns, with double trigger mechanism on a rail basis. An interesting thing, however, in this form it is possible to throw it at someone.
 
 
%c[default]SPECIFICATIONS:
%c[0,153,255,255] ï %c[0,140,140,140,140] military object
%c[255,238,153,26] ï %c[0,140,140,140,140,140] is used with:%c[0,170,170,170] care of weapons (+20%)
Duplex frame with buttstock and trigger mechanism

Duplex frame assembled from various parts from disassembled shotguns and machine guns, with a double trigger mechanism on a rail basis and with a convenient customizable buttstock. Interesting specimen, but lacking the most important detail.

Silencer PBS-1

%c[default]SPECIFICATIONS: 
 
%c[0,153,255,255] ï %c[default] 7,62x39 caliber
 
%c[0,170,170,170]PBS-1 is a Soviet/Russian silencer for 7,62x39 caliber weapons. Although production began in the 1950s, it is still quite effective and continues to be produced for AK, AKM, AK-103, and AK-104 assault rifles. The silencer is enclosed in a steel cylindrical body and consists of an expansion chamber, followed by 11 compartments separated by ten steel partitions. Initially, the silencer contained a rubber skirt, which was later replaced by a high quality polymer analogue that does not require such frequent replacement. 
 
%c[0.93,0,116] ï %c[0.140,140,140,140] Muffling sound: %c[0.170,170,170]average

%c[0,153,255,255] ï %c[0,140,140,140,140]rifle magazine for AK series
5.45x39mm caliber bakelite magazine

Bakelite magazine for 30 rounds of 5.45x39mm caliber. Bakelite is a material formed by the initial stage of resin synthesis. This material resists pressure, friction, shocks and blows well. Water, diluted alkalis and acids do not work on Bakelite, it is resistant to temperatures up to 300 degrees Celsius. For 7.62x39 magazines, the main color of the grocery magazine is orange, for 5.45 - plum and black. The disadvantage of the magazine is only its colouring.
